news_summary: A Florida tribe is actively opposing the construction of an immigrant detention center, demonstrating strong community engagement in protecting their environment and local heritage. Their efforts highlight a growing movement to safeguard natural and cultural resources from potentially harmful developments.
news_summary_fr: Une tribu de Floride s'oppose activement à la construction d'un centre de détention pour immigrés, faisant preuve d'un engagement communautaire fort pour protéger son environnement et son patrimoine local. Leurs efforts mettent en lumière un mouvement croissant de sauvegarde des ressources naturelles et culturelles contre des développements potentiellement néfastes.
news_summary_es: Una tribu de Florida se opone activamente a la construcción de un centro de detención de inmigrantes, demostrando un fuerte compromiso comunitario para proteger su medio ambiente y su patrimonio local. Sus esfuerzos ponen de relieve un movimiento creciente para salvaguardar los recursos naturales y culturales de proyectos potencialmente perjudiciales.

articles.title: A tribe in Florida joins the fight against the ‘Alligator Alcatraz’ immigrant detention center
articles.content:
The Miccosukee Tribe in Florida joined environmental groups on Tuesday to sue the federal and state agencies that constructed an immigrant detention center known as the “Alligator Alcatraz” and located in the Everglades National Park.

In a motion to join a lawsuit, as one of the first tribes to potentially sue against the detention center, the case argues that the Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Miami-Dade County, and the Florida Division of Emergency Management did not seek an environmental review.

The filing alleges the center’s proximity to Miccosukee villages, ceremonial sites, and access to traditional hunting grounds, and “raises significant raises significant concerns about environmental degradation and potential impacts.”

“We are going to make sure that we fight this facility on whatever front is available to us,” said William “Popeye” James Osecola, who is the secretary of the Miccosukee tribal council. He hopes the lawsuit will “signify that the tribe will continue fighting to do what it’s always done, which is protect the land and save the land that saved us.”

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

According to Osecola, since the facility’s operation began, tribal members have been restricted from gathering plants and roots for uses such as medicine. “Obviously, that’s not an option for us right now,” he said. “At the moment, it’s the first time we’ve ever seen gates like that there, so it’s very jarring for us.”

Nearby the facility, 15 active tribal villages reside inside Big Cypress National Preserve, located within the Everglades.

During the 19th century, the Seminole Wars, which the Seminole Nation and Miccosukee Nation view as one continuous conflict against the U.S., many members fled into the wetlands and used their natural environment as refuge.

Protestors stand outside a makeshift detention center for immigrants known as the “Alligator Alcatraz” as government vehicles drive by, in the Florida Everglades. Betty Osceola

In a press conference at the detention center last month, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis said there would be “zero impact” on the wetland’s environment. The site is located on an abandoned airstrip, once a controversial project that aimed to be the world’s largest airport. Observers outside the facility said they could see lights on at all hours, attracting mosquito swarms. Recent satellite images also reveal that a freshly paved road has been laid down.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Last year, the tribe and the National Park Service signed a co-stewardship agreement for Everglades National Park. The partnership aimed to collaborate on protecting tribal practices, restoration efforts for the land’s vegetation, and protection.

In these cypress swamps and toothy sawgrass marshes, wildlife alongside alligators includes bats, turtles, and panthers. Because species such as the panther are critically endangered, Osecola implied that the continuous traffic at Alligator Alcatraz will “see more deaths with the wildlife”. “It’s taken decades just to get Everglades restoration going like it is now,” he said.

While the Department of Homeland Security distanced itself after promoting the facility for weeks, claiming Florida controls the facility under state hands, critics are not convinced. Elise Bennett, Florida and Caribbean director at the Center for Biological Diversity, an organization that filed alongside Friends of the Everglades in the case last month, noted that “setting aside the funding for detaining immigrants is essentially a federal function. This is a federal project, regardless of what they say in their court filings.”

Last week, the Center for Biological Diversity filed a legal notice with an intent to sue that the construction also violates the Clean Water Act and Endangered Species Act, raising concerns such as light pollution and the use of insecticide to mitigate mosquitoes on-site that could affect the area’s wildlife and surrounding water.

Each day since its opening, protestors and groups have noticed trucks coming in carrying diesel, generators, and caged vehicles holding detainees. There are currently 3000 beds inside the facility and at least 400 security personnel on-site.

After state legislators were blocked from entering the Alligator Alcatraz’s premises, Governor DeSantis invited legislators and the state’s members of Congress to tour the facility over the weekend. According to Osecola, the Governor of Florida did not extend that invitation to tribes.

Some Republican members claimed that the detention center was clean and safe. Others, such as Democratic State Representative Anna Eskamani, reported that, “The environmental impact of this facility cannot be overstated — there is new asphalt, thousands of gallons of water used every day and gas tanks powering generators. No alligators seen, but plenty of mosquitoes.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the Miccosukee Tribe and environmental groups taking legal action to protect the Everglades and tribal lands from environmental harm caused by the immigrant detention center. This reflects community and indigenous efforts to conserve the environment and preserve cultural heritage, which is positive and hopeful despite the ongoing challenges.
articles.personality_title: Florida tribe stands up to protect Everglades from detention center
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The Miccosukee Tribe in Florida is known for its deep connection to the Everglades, a unique and precious natural area.

**What happened**
The tribe teamed up with environmental groups to sue government agencies over a new immigrant detention center called 'Alligator Alcatraz' built in the Everglades National Park.

**Impact**
This legal action highlights the tribe’s commitment to protecting their land and the environment from harm, showing how communities can come together to defend nature and cultural heritage.

**What's next step**
The case will move forward as the tribe and allies push for a review of the detention center’s impact and seek to prevent further damage to the Everglades.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A Florida tribe is courageously joining forces to defend their homeland and the environment from threats, inspiring hope for nature’s protection.
articles.personality_title_fr: La tribu de Floride résiste pour protéger les Everglades du centre de détention
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
La tribu Miccosukee en Floride est connue pour sa connexion profonde avec les Everglades, une zone naturelle unique et précieuse.

**ce qui s'est passé**
La tribu s'est associée à des groupes environnementaux pour poursuivre les agences gouvernementales sur un nouveau centre de détention des immigrants appelée «Alligator Alcatraz» construit dans le parc national des Everglades.

**Impact**
Cette action en justice met en évidence l'engagement de la tribu à protéger leurs terres et l'environnement contre les dommages, montrant comment les communautés peuvent se réunir pour défendre la nature et le patrimoine culturel.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
L'affaire va de l'avant à mesure que la tribu et les alliés poussent à un examen de l'impact du centre de détention et cherchent à éviter d'autres dommages aux Everglades.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Une tribu de Floride s'associe courageusement à défendre leur patrie et l'environnement contre les menaces, inspirant l'espoir pour la protection de la nature.
articles.personality_title_es: La tribu de Florida se pone de pie para proteger los Everglades del Centro de Detención
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
La tribu Miccosukee en Florida es conocida por su profunda conexión con los Everglades, un área natural única y preciosa.

**Qué pasó**
La tribu se asoció con grupos ambientalistas para demandar a las agencias gubernamentales por un nuevo centro de detención de inmigrantes llamado 'Alligator Alcatraz' construido en el Parque Nacional Everglades.

**Impacto**
Esta acción legal destaca el compromiso de la tribu de proteger su tierra y el medio ambiente de daños, mostrando cómo las comunidades pueden unirse para defender la naturaleza y el patrimonio cultural.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
El caso avanzará a medida que la tribu y los aliados impulsen una revisión del impacto del centro de detención y buscarán evitar más daños a los Everglades.

**Control de una oración**
Una tribu de Florida está uniendo valientemente fuerzas para defender su tierra natal y el medio ambiente de las amenazas, inspirando la esperanza para la protección de la naturaleza.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a serene Everglades landscape featuring a protective alligator watching over peaceful cypress swamps and sawgrass marshes, with symbolic tribal totems subtly integrated among the wetlands, surrounded by gentle silhouettes of panthers and turtles moving freely under a soft, natural palette of greens, browns, and blues.
